At 13:15 23/05/2005, you wrote:
>(3) Most MSc:s are not failed PhD:s - in fact, doing an MSc is far
>more common than doing a PhD, and in practice more or less a
>prerequisite for being accepted for a PhD, at least a funded one. Me,
>and every PhD student I know, got registered for a three-year PhD
>straight away, after having completed a one-year MSc, possibly in some
>other university.

Sorry, didn't mean to imply MScs were failed PhDs.  Obviously a lot of 
people do MScs quite deliberately.

If what you say about most PhDs generally needing an MSc as a prerequisite 
is correct (and obviously, I've got no reason to call you a liar :), then 
that is a change I didn't pick up on (although, I suppose in retrospect I 
did see a lot more MSc students that I might have expected, back when I was 
co-supervising student projects)...

>(4) The postgraduate tuition fee for an EU national, or EU resident,
>is about 3 000 pounds/year. For non-EU people it is about 10 000, a
>hefty amount. But after having studied in Scotland for four years, you
>might be considered an EU resident. The rules are tricky - an MA
>student I know, being a Canadian citizen, managed to get the lower fee
>after showing that she was registered with the Spanish authorities as
>resident in Spain for the last few years, which she had in fact spent
>in Indonesia. But she sure knew how to argue those things. Another
>friend of mine got both tuition and living expenses funded by the
>University of West of England, even though he's from Norway, which is
>oddly enough not part of the EU.
>
>I completely agree with what Ian says about supervisors.
>
>(By the way, Ian, you mentioned a position paper about modularity some
>time - is that available?)

         It's not a paper in the appearing in a Journal sense (because (i) 
I'm not in a university and (ii) I don't have time to write a "proper" paper).

         I'm still writing it up as a wed-document but Hofstadter's law 
definitely applies.  I've got, say, 75% of the text in place, but what's 
left is a bit diagram intensive... and then I need to fill in some 
references and a glossary.  And then just review the whole thing to be sure 
that my terminology hasn't changed as I was going through (which I know for 
a fact some of it did).

         To help you tell whether you want to wait for this, here is the 
summary page.  This will get rewritten a bit for the final draft, but the 
general drift will be the same:


1.2 summary




Synopsis

A position-document for the definition of evolving agents and research 
outline for this under-explored area of artificial intelligence. This 
proposal concerns embedding existing evolving software techniques (such as 
Genetic Programming and Neural Nets) inside co-evolving support frameworks 
with the intention of increased evolvability, robustness, scalability and 
modularity.

----------


Summary

This document proposes a new area of <http://www.aaai.org/>Artificial 
Intelligence (AI) research. It does not propose any huge and improbable 
breakthrough, but documents an area where useful progress can be made.

Many evolving software techniques already exist, such as:
    * <http://www.genetic-programming.org/>Genetic Programming (GP)
    * <http://www.faqs.org/faqs/ai-faq/neural-nets/>Artificial Neural Nets 
(ANN) Although traditionally "trained", more recent techniques started to 
evolve them with considerable success)
    * Genetic algorithms (GA)
    * Evolutionary Programming (EP)
    * Evolution Strategies (ES)
    * Classifier Systems.
See <http://www-2.cs.cmu.edu/Groups/AI/html/faqs/ai/genetic/top.html>here 
for help distinguishing between evolutionary techniques.

Although initially set up for the first two of these -- GP and ANN -- the 
ideas outlined here are applicable to any of them, and potentially to any 
"adaptive" or "learning" algorithm.

The idea behind this document is that these techniques have the potential 
to evolve, and under "hothouse" conditions they do. They do not, however, 
exhibit the robustness or versatility of natural evolving systems. This is 
because the techniques are "naked". In the same sense that DNA in a test 
tube is naked. Pour in the right chemicals and the naked DNA will replicate 
-- but it is hardly a viable organism.

In nature, the cell which surrounds a strand of DNA provides "services" to 
the DNA. Services which not only support the day-to-day life of the 
organism, but also support evolution -- sometimes through action (e.g. 
intron splicing) but often just by their nature. Later I will devote an 
appendix to how protein chemistry is a perfect system to support the 
evolution of DNA.

This support for evolution is called "evolvability". and the fundamental 
premise of this document is that there is a lot more that can be done to 
supply evolvability in evolving computer systems. This document therefore 
proposes:
    * A definition for an Evolving Agent (EA) in terms of principles it 
should satisfy.
    * Tests for those principles.
    * A broad approach to achieving an EA by wrapping existing evolving 
technologies in a co-evolving support framework (CSF).
    * Properties that the CSF will need to exhibit.
    * A preliminary design for a CSF.
Ian
